   \(101 \times 19 = 1919\)  
   \(2008-1919 = 89\)

   So \(2008 \equiv 89 \pmod{101}\).
   To leave a multiple of 101 you must take exactly 89 eggs, because

   \(2008-89 = 1919 = 101 \times 19\).

5. Check that 89 is an admissible move (it is between 1 and 100).

Hence, by taking 89 eggs first and thereafter mirroring
your opponent’s moves to make the two–turn total 101,
you are guaranteed to take the very last egg and win.

Final answer: 89

Question:
Question: There are 3 numbers 0-9.
Eric knows the product and says, "I know the numbers."
Then, everyone is told that one digit is exactly one greater than another.
Then, Luke is told one of the numbers and says, "Eric lied."
Then you are told the numbers add up to 11.
What are the numbers?
 Hint: There are only so many combinations if two of the digits must be adjacent...
Hint: There are only so many combinations if two of the digits must be adjacent...
Human Solution:
0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.

Question:
Question: What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
 Hint: Think mathematically.
Hint: Think mathematically.
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
Let us convert each letter to its position in the English alphabet  
(A = 1, B = 2, …, Z = 26).

Row 1: O Q L H R → 15 17 12 8 18  
Row 2: I J F E Q →  9 10  6 5 17  
Row 3: F G F C ? →  6  7  6 3 ?

Now check whether Row 3 is obtained by subtracting Row 2 from Row 1, term-by-term:

15 − 9 = 6   → 6 = F ✔  
17 − 10 = 7 → 7 = G ✔  
12 − 6 = 6  → 6 = F ✔  
8 − 5 = 3   → 3 = C ✔

Thus the pattern holds. For the last position:

18 − 17 = 1 → 1 = A.

Hence the missing letter is A.

Final answer: A

Question:
Question: It is a sunny and warm spring day in Cipher, South Decoder. Fans at the baseball park have come to see their own Cipher Solvers play their rivals, the Rockford Peaches, in the first game of the season. Everyone is hoping for a good show.
The home fans became very vocal as 5 of their players (Tim, Hank, K.C., Flynn, and Jimmy Blake) either made an exciting play to allow runs to score, or made an embarrassing error - or both!
Scorecard
Names: Tim, Hank, K.C., Flynn, Jimmy Blake
Positions: pitcher, catcher, 3rd base, shortstop, left field
RBIs: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
Errors: 0, 1, ?, 2, 3
First Inning
By the end of the game, two players were charged with the same number of errors, either 1 or 2. This number (?) is to be deduced from the clues.
Second Inning
No player ended up with the same number of errors and RBIs.
Third Inning
The left fielder had his 1 RBI when, with runners at 1st and 3rd, he hit one over the head of the Peaches' 2nd baseman and into right field.
Fourth Inning
Jimmy Blake earned his 2 RBIs when he hit a triple, allowing the center fielder and the 3rd baseman to score.
Fifth Inning
Flynn had his 1 error when he missed a throw to 1st base.
Sixth Inning
Tim, who posted either 2 or 3 RBIs, ended up with 1 error more than the pitcher after he (Tim) quite literally dropped the ball.
Seventh Inning
The player who finished with no RBIs and 2 errors, including fumbling a fly ball, doesn't play 3rd base.
Eighth Inning
The player who had his 3 RBIs with a game-tying in-the-park home run that had the fans on their feet, scored at least 1 error, but he had fewer errors than the shortstop.
Ninth Inning
K.C. ended the game with 2 fewer errors than the catcher, who let a wild pitch get past him so that the Peaches regained the lead.
Can you determine which position the boys played, as well as how many runs batted in (RBI) and errors they made?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution:
Hank (catcher) with 0 RBIs and 2 errors
K.C. (left field) with 1 RBI and 0 errors
Jimmy Blake (shortstop) with 2 RBIs and 3 errors
Tim (3rd base) with 3 RBIs and 2 errors
Flynn (pitcher) with 4 RBIs and 1 error

Question:
Question: A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
 Hint: 1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for R, U, O, N, or V
? stands for U, D, L, W, or J
@ stands for A, G, P, E, or Y
; stands for O, M, I, C, or S
The four letter code word, @!;?, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Hint: Morality
Hint: Morality
Human Solution: Good and Evil.
Response:
We are told that each of the four symbols can stand for any one of five letters:

@ → A, G, P, E, Y  
!  → R, U, O, N, V  
;  → O, M, I, C, S  
? → U, D, L, W, J  

The coded word is @!;?; we must pick one letter from each symbol’s set so that we obtain an English word.  Moreover, there are two different English words obtainable this way, and the two words are opposites.  The hint “Morality” suggests we look for antonyms such as GOOD / BAD, VICE / VIRTUE, etc.

1. Start with the hint “Morality.”  A classic pair of moral opposites is GOOD and EVIL, both 4-letter words.
2. Check whether each letter of GOOD can be obtained from the corresponding symbol’s set.

   @ (1st position): G ∈ {A,G,P,E,Y} ✔  
   ! (2nd): O ∈ {R,U,O,N,V} ✔  
   ; (3rd): O ∈ {O,M,I,C,S} ✔  
   ? (4th): D ∈ {U,D,L,W,J} ✔  

   So GOOD is a valid decoding of @!;?.

3. Check EVIL.

   @ (1st): E ∈ {A,G,P,E,Y} ✔  
   ! (2nd): V ∈ {R,U,O,N,V} ✔  
   ; (3rd): I ∈ {O,M,I,C,S} ✔  
   ? (4th): L ∈ {U,D,L,W,J} ✔  

   EVIL is also a valid decoding.

Since GOOD and EVIL are opposites in morality and both conform to the symbol–letter constraints, they are the required pair.

Final answer: GOOD and EVIL

Question:
Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
 Hint: Calendar differences?
Hint: Calendar differences?
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
The three men really were born on the same little street in Jerusalem, but the “year” that was written for each of them was recorded with the calendar that his own religious community used.

• Adam was a Jew.  His birth was entered as 1309 in the Hebrew (Anno Mundi) calendar;  
  Anno Mundi 1309 = 3761 – 1309 = 2452 BCE (approximately).

• Ben was a Christian.  His birth was written down as 1310 in the (Julian / Gregorian) Christian era, i.e. 1310 CE.

• Cyril was a Muslim.  His birth year was recorded as 1311 in the Islamic (Hijri) calendar;  
  1311 AH ≈ 1893 CE.

Thus

Adam lived roughly 2452–2390 BCE,  
Ben lived roughly 1310–1375 CE,  
Cyril lived roughly 1893–1958 CE.

Each man lived more than sixty years, all on the same road – but their lifetimes were separated from one another by many centuries, so their paths could never have crossed.

Final answer: The three “consecutive” years are from three different calendars (Hebrew, Christian, and Islamic), so the men were actually born centuries apart and therefore never lived at the same time.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Hint: In music...
Hint: In music...
Human Solution: Forte and Piano.
Response:
We are told that each symbol in the five-character “code word” (+_*) can stand for one of five possible letters:

(  →  Y  T  E  P  F  
+  →  N  G  I  O  X  
_  →  R  B  M  A  S  
*  →  L  T  K  C  N  
)  →  D  O  E  H  S  

The code word is the five symbols

(  +  _  *  )

so we must choose one letter from the proper set for each position:

1st letter from {Y,T,E,P,F}  
2nd letter from {N,G,I,O,X}  
3rd letter from {R,B,M,A,S}  
4th letter from {L,T,K,C,N}  
5th letter from {D,O,E,H,S}  

The hint says “In music…”, so we look for a pair of five-letter musical terms that are opposites.  
The obvious dynamic opposites are

FORTE  (loud)  
PIANO  (soft)

Check that both words fit the constraints:

FORTE  
F ∈ {Y,T,E,P,F} ✔  
O ∈ {N,G,I,O,X} ✔  
R ∈ {R,B,M,A,S} ✔  
T ∈ {L,T,K,C,N} ✔  
E ∈ {D,O,E,H,S} ✔  

PIANO  
P ∈ {Y,T,E,P,F} ✔  
I ∈ {N,G,I,O,X} ✔  
A ∈ {R,B,M,A,S} ✔  
N ∈ {L,T,K,C,N} ✔  
O ∈ {D,O,E,H,S} ✔  

Thus the single code (+_*) can legitimately be decoded in two ways, giving the opposite musical terms “FORTE” and “PIANO”.

Final answer: FORTE and PIANO

Question:
Question: The following statements were made by each of eight people at a family reunion. They are each referring to one of the other seven people (in other words the person being referred to in the first statement, Maria, is making one of the other statements). Can you determine who made each statement? Assume that all parents are married and that all married couples are heterosexual, married only once, still married, and attending together.
1.  "I am Maria's niece."
2.  "Christopher is my only cousin."
3.  "Clarissa is my brother's wife."
4.  "I am Donna's sister."
5.  "Jonathan is my uncle."
6.  "Theodore is my brother."
7.  "Ben is my nephew."
8.  "Judy is my daughter."
 Hint: I started with the women:  I used statements 1 and 3 to put Maria and Clarissa in the older generation, respectively. Keep deducing...
Hint: I started with the women:  I used statements 1 and 3 to put Maria and Clarissa in the older generation, respectively. Keep deducing...
Human Solution:
1.  Donna
2.  Ben
3.  Theodore
4.  Judy
5.  Christopher
6.  Jonathan
7.  Maria
8.  Clarissa
I had trouble coming up with a nice, straightforward logical solution for this problem so I had to use a little trial and error.  Since no grandchildren are mentioned, I assumed that there were only two generations present.  I started with the women:  I used statements 1 and 3 to put Maria and Clarissa in the older generation, respectively.  Then I used statements 4 and 8 to put Donna and Judy in the younger generation, as sisters.  Statement 7 puts Ben in the younger generation.  If Christopher is also in the younger generation, then Ben must be Donna and Judy's brother and either Ben or Donna says statement 2.  If Theodore and Jonathan are in the older generation, then Jonathan must be Clarissa's husband and Theodore must be Jonathan's brother (Statement 3).  Statement 1 has to be said by Donna, since she is the only girl left in the younger generation who could say that.  This leaves Ben saying statement 2.  By elimination, Clarissa must give statement 8 and Maria statement 7.  The only thing left is for Christopher to make statement 5.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Hint: Law
Hint: Law
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response:
We are told that the five-symbol code “*/+-=” can be read in English by replacing each symbol with one letter chosen from its own small list.

Symbol → possible letters  
*  → B  O  P  F  C  
/  → F  N  H  E  R  
+  → D  G  I  M  A  
-  → E  O  L  C  W  
=  → J  K  U  R  S  

So a decoded word must have the pattern

1 2 3 4 5  
* / + - =  
{B,C,F,O,P} {E,F,H,N,R} {A,D,G,I,M} {C,E,L,O,W} {J,K,U,R,S}

We need two different 5-letter English words obtainable from this pattern that are antonyms.

Step 1: Look for ordinary English words that fit the pattern.

• Consider words ending in R or S (because = can be R or S).  
• Restrict the 4th letter to C, E, L, O, W.

Searching mentally (or systematically) yields

ORDER : O R D E R  
Check letters against the lists:  
O∈* , R∈/ , D∈+ , E∈- , R∈=   → valid.

Now seek a 5-letter antonym of ORDER that might also fit.

CHAOS : C H A O S  
C∈* , H∈/ , A∈+ , O∈- , S∈=   → also valid.

Step 2: Verify they are opposites.

Order and chaos are standard antonyms; “Law” (given as a hint) contrasts with “Chaos” in many philosophical/game contexts (“Law vs Chaos”).

Hence the coded sequence “*/+-=” can translate to either

ORDER or CHAOS,

two opposite English words.

Final answer: ORDER and CHAOS

Question:
Question: runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
 Hint: Look within the spellings...
Hint: Look within the spellings...
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Notice that each given word has six letters.  
    run w a y  
    cin e m a  
    ans w e r  

2.  Look at the middle two letters (positions 3 and 4) of each word.  
       runway → N W  
       cinema → N E  
       answer → S W  

   These pairs of letters are the standard abbreviations for compass directions:
   NW (north-west), NE (north-east), SW (south-west).

3.  Three of the four diagonals of the compass rose are already present.  
   The one still missing is SE (south-east).

4.  Therefore we need any six-letter word whose middle two letters are “SE”.
   Many words fit, e.g. abSEnt, inSErt, biSEct, caSEin, etc.

5.  Choosing one of them, we can complete the ratio:

   runway : cinema :: answer : insert

   (since “insert” has “SE” as its middle two letters).

Final answer: insert

Question:
Question: John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
 Hint: This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart. If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade sat at home, waiting for his favourite TV program "I'm a celebrity, Get me a Kebab" to start. He glanced at his clock and began to wonder strange and wondrous things, but that is another story altogether.
He realised that he could leave 6 adjacent numbers of the face of a clock intact and rearrange the other 6 in such a way that the sum of every pair of adjacent numbers is prime.
Unfortunately the TV program started at that point so he never actually got around to doing it. Can you find the two possible solutions to Mad Ade's clock teaser?
 Hint: Part of it is making sure each number is odd...
Hint: Part of it is making sure each number is odd...
Human Solution:
Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Response:
Step-1 :  What the sums have to look like  
Except for the prime 2, every prime is odd, so every required
“adjacent–sum’’ must be odd.  
Consequently every neighbouring pair on the finished clock has to
consist of one even and one odd number – the numbers round the finished
dial must therefore alternate even, odd, even, odd … all the way round.

Step-2 :  Which six consecutive numbers may stay where they are?  
Write the ordinary clock numbers round a circle and look at the sums of
neighbouring numbers that are already there:

1+2 = 3 (P) 2+3 = 5 (P) 3+4 = 7 (P) 4+5 = 9 (×)  
5+6 = 11 (P) 6+7 = 13 (P) 7+8 = 15 (×)  
8+9 = 17 (P) 9+10 = 19 (P) 10+11 = 21 (×)  
11+12 = 23 (P) 12+1 = 13 (P)

Only three adjacent pairs are not prime: 4-5, 7-8 and 10-11.  
Thus the unique string of 6 consecutive numbers that contains no
“bad’’ edge is

 … 11 – 12 – 1 – 2 – 3 – 4 …

Hence these six numbers (11, 12, 1, 2, 3, 4) must be the block that
stays exactly where it is.

Step-3 :  What has to be done with the other six places?  
The remaining six positions (those now labelled 5,6,7,8,9,10) must be
filled with the six unused numbers 5,6,7,8,9,10 so that

4 + (number in place 5)  and  (number in place 10) + 11 are prime  
and every pair inside the block (place 5 to place 10) also sums to a
prime.

Step-4 :  The small prime-sum graph  
Inside the moving block the possible prime pairs are

5–6, 5–8, 6–7, 7–10, 8–9, 9–10.

These six numbers therefore form the 6-cycle

5 – 6 – 7 – 10 – 9 – 8 – 5.

Step-5 :  The two admissible end-points  
• 4+? is prime only for ? = 7 or 9 → first number of the block is 7 or 9.  
• ?+11 is prime only for ? = 6 or 8 → last number of the block is 6 or 8.

For a Hamiltonian path along the 6-cycle to exist the two end-vertices
have to be adjacent on that cycle.  
The adjacent pairs among {7,9}×{6,8} are (7,6) and (9,8); the other two
combinations fail.

Step-6 :  Building the two paths

(a)  Start 7, finish 6  
Long way round the cycle: 7 – 10 – 9 – 8 – 5 – 6.

(b)  Start 9, finish 8  
Long way round the cycle: 9 – 10 – 7 – 6 – 5 – 8.

Step-7 :  The two complete clock-faces

Solution 1 (starting from 12 o’clock and going clockwise)
12 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 7 , 10 , 9 , 8 , 5 , 6 , 11

Solution 2
12 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 9 , 10 , 7 , 6 , 5 , 8 , 11

In every one of the two arrangements every neighbouring pair of numbers
adds up to a prime, while the six consecutive numbers
11–12–1–2–3–4 stay exactly where they were on the original clock.

Final answer:  
12 1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11  
12 1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11

Question:
Question: There are 10 people who could be the owner of the bank. They all sit in separate chairs across a long table facing north. The table is made of aluminium. The owner of the bank sits next to M. M sits on the left side of the banker. M sits next to C. C sits 4 places to the left of L. L sits next to O and rarely talks to S, E or Z, because they hate him and because they sit on the far right of the bank. O does not sit next to the owner of the bank. The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank and is considering resigning. Give the names of all the bankers from left to right.
 Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Human Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Response:
Reasoning step-by-step  

1.  Let the ten seats be numbered 1 (extreme left) to 10 (extreme right).  
2.  The three people S, E and Z “sit on the far right of the bank”, so put them in seats 8, 9 and 10 (order still unknown).  
3.  C is four places to the left of L.  To avoid the reserved far-right seats, the only ways this can happen are  
      • C-1 & L-5, • C-2 & L-6, • C-3 & L-7.  
   (If C were 4, 5 or 6, L would fall in seat 8, 9 or 10, which are already taken.)  
4.  L must sit next to O.  If L were in seat 7 (the C-3 case) then O would have to be in seat 8, but 8 is already S/E/Z; impossible.  
   So we are left with two viable pairs:  
      A) C-1, L-5 or B) C-2, L-6.  
5.  M sits next to C and is on the banker’s (owner’s) left.  The banker must sit immediately to the right of M.  
   • If C is in seat 2 (pair B), M could be in seat 1 or 3.  
         – M 1 would force the banker into seat 2 (already C) – impossible.  
         – So M must be seat 3 and the banker seat 4.  
         – Now O must be next to L (6); choosing O 5 would place O next to the banker (4) which is forbidden, so O has to be seat 7.  
         – This leaves L (6) only two seats away from the “far-right” block (8-9-10), contradicting the statement that he “rarely talks to S, E or Z … because they sit on the far right.”  
      Hence pair B is rejected.  
   • Accept pair A: C 1, L 5.  
         – C in seat 1 forces M into seat 2 (the only adjacent seat).  
         – Banker therefore occupies seat 3.  
         – To keep O next to L (5) but not next to the banker (3) we must put O in seat 6 (not seat 4).  
6.  Seats now fixed:  
      1 C 2 M 3 Banker 4 ? 5 L 6 O 7 ? 8-9-10 = S,E,Z (in some order).  
7.  The only names still unseated are F and T.  
   T “hates the owner of the bank”, so put T as far from the owner (seat 3) as possible, i.e. seat 7, and F in the remaining seat 4.  
8.  One admissible order for the three “far-right” seats is S 8, E 9, Z 10 (any permutation of S,E,Z would also satisfy the wording).  

Thus the complete arrangement from left to right is  

Seat 1  C  
Seat 2  M  
Seat 3  (Owner / Banker)  
Seat 4  F  
Seat 5  L  
Seat 6  O  
Seat 7  T  
Seat 8  S  
Seat 9  E  
Seat 10 Z  

Final answer: C, M, Banker, F, L, O, T, S, E, Z.

Question:
Question: You and your spouse invite four other couples to a party. During the course of the conversation, it is discovered that, prior to the party, each person except you was acquainted with a different number of the people present. Assuming the acquaintance relationship is symmetric (i.e., if you are acquainted with someone, that person is also acquainted with you), then how many people did your spouse know prior to the party? How many people did you know?
 Hint: Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person.
Hint: Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person.
Human Solution:
Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Response:
Let the ten people present be arranged in couples  
(you Y , your spouse S), (A , a), (B , b), (C , c), (D , d).

For every person but you the number of people he (or she) knew before the
party is different.  
Consequently, among those nine people the possible numbers of
acquaintances 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8 all occur exactly once.

Step 1.  Somebody knows 0 people – so a spouse can be unknown.  
The hint asks us to assume first that every couple were acquainted.
If that were true, nobody could have “0’’ acquaintances, yet 0 is one of the
nine different numbers.  Hence at least one couple did **not** know each other
before the party.

Step 2.  The person with 0 acquaintances is married to the person with 8.  
Call the person who knew nobody P₀ and the person who knew 8 people P₈.

• P₀ knows no one, so in particular he does not know his own spouse.  
  Therefore P₀’s spouse is counted among the eight people P₀ does **not**
  know.

• P₈ knows everybody except P₀ (otherwise P₈ would have 9 acquaintances,
  impossible).  Hence P₈ knows P₀’s spouse.

If P₀’s spouse were **not** P₈, then P₀’s spouse would be known both by P₈
and by someone else (him-/herself), giving that spouse at least two
acquaintances – contradicting the fact that every available number of
acquaintances occurs exactly once (the numbers 1…7 are already accounted
for elsewhere).  Thus the only possibility is that P₀’s spouse is P₈.

So the couple (P₀ , P₈) has acquaintance numbers 0 and 8; their
numbers sum to 8.

Step 3.  Remove that couple and repeat.  
Discard P₀ and P₈ and look at the remaining seven people.
Exactly the same reasoning pairs

 1 with 7, 2 with 6, 3 with 5.

In every case the two spouses’ acquaintance numbers add up to 8.

Step 4.  The only unpaired number is 4 – it must belong to your spouse.  
After forming the four couples above, eight of the nine numbers
0,1,2,3,5,6,7,8 have been used; the only number still unused is 4.
The remaining person among the nine is your spouse S, so

  S knew 4 people before the party.

Step 5.  Your own number must complement your spouse’s to 8.  
Exactly the same argument that paired every other couple shows that for
any married pair the two acquaintance numbers must add to 8.  (If one knew
k people, then among the remaining nine there are 8–k people he does not
know, and his spouse must be one of them; thus the spouse’s number is
8–k.)

Because your spouse’s number is 4, yours must be 8–4 = 4 as well.

Conclusion.  Before the party

 your spouse knew 4 of the people present, and  
 you yourself also knew 4 of the people present.

Final answer: spouse knew 4 people, and you knew 4 people.

Question:
Question: Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
 Hint: nan
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1. Nick has “always wanted one”, so he goes out and buys a brand-new one for £5 000.  
   • There are not many everyday objects whose first purchase legitimately costs thousands of pounds while subsequent identical copies are cheap.  
   • One clear example is a personalised (cherished) vehicle registration mark.  
     – You pay a large one-off fee to the DVLA or to a dealer for the right to use a particular registration “number”.  
     – Once you own the right, the plastic plates that actually go on the car cost only a few pounds.

2. “Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand-new one. This time however, it only costs him £25.”  
   • He does not lose the registration right; he merely cracks or smashes the physical acrylic plate on the car.  
   • Replacing the broken plate with a brand-new plate bearing the same registration mark is inexpensive (around £20–£30).

3. “The next day someone offers to buy it off him for £6 000.”  
   • People trade desirable registration marks; once Nick owns the right he can sell it on, often for more than he paid.  
   • A £6 000 offer for a plate he bought for £5 000 is perfectly plausible.

4. The hint “nan” (“NaN” = Not-a-Number) quietly points toward the idea of a “number” that is, in a sense, not really a number—i.e. a car “number” plate.

Therefore the object that fits all three money amounts and the hint is a personalised vehicle registration number (the plastic number plate that represents it may be cheap, but the right to the mark is expensive).

Final answer: A personalised car registration/number plate.

Question:
Question: Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
 Hint: prime...
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Let the six different, non–zero integers we are looking for be  

 J , A , N , E , U , Y  

(one for every different letter that appears in the four names).

From the statement of the problem we have

 Jane : J + A + N + E = 16             (1)  
 June : J + U + N + E = 17             (2)  
 Jean : J + A + N + E = 16      (same as (1))  
 Jenny : J + E + N + N + Y = 19 ⇒ J + E + 2N + Y = 19  (3)

Subtracting (1) from (2):

 U − A = 1  ⇒ U = A + 1          (4)

Subtracting (1) from (3):

 N + Y − A = 3  ⇒ Y = A + 3 − N     (5)

─────────────────────────────  
The hint “June is in her prime” is meant to be taken literally:  
every letter that appears in the name J U N E must be assigned a prime
number.  (There are exactly four one–digit primes: 2, 3, 5, 7; hence
each of J, U, N, E must be one of these four, used once each.)

Therefore

 {J, U, N, E} = {2, 3, 5, 7}    with each value used exactly once.     (6)

Because of (4) U = A + 1, U must be one of the primes 3, 5, 7; the
corresponding value of A is then 2, 4, 6.  
Checking these three possibilities quickly shows that only

 U = 7  and hence A = 6

works: it is the sole choice that allows all six letters to receive
different values while keeping Y positive and different from the other
five numbers (via (5)).

With A fixed at 6 and U fixed at 7, condition (1) becomes

 J + N + E = 10.                                             (7)

The only way to write 10 as the sum of three different one–digit primes
is 2 + 3 + 5.  Thus {J, N, E} = {2, 3, 5}.  
There are two distinct ways to distribute 2 and 3 between J and E
(while N is 5), and each of them determines Y from (5):

 • If N = 5,  J = 2,  E = 3 ⇒ Y = 6 + 3 − 5 = 4.  
 • If N = 5,  J = 3,  E = 2 ⇒ Y = 6 + 3 − 5 = 4.

Both sets satisfy all the original requirements, and no other assignment
does.  Hence there are exactly two solutions.

─────────────────────────────
Final answer:  

(1) J = 2, A = 6, N = 5, E = 3, U = 7, Y = 4  

(2) J = 3, A = 6, N = 5, E = 2, U = 7, Y = 4

Question:
Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet. Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
 Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
Let  

 n = the number of days Kevin is exactly right.  
 Then Kathy is right twice as often (2n days) and  
 Kate is right once less often ((n-1) days).  

There are 21 weekdays from Monday, 3-March to Monday, 31-March:

5 (Mar 3-7) + 5 (Mar 10-14) + 5 (Mar 17-21) + 5 (Mar 24-28) + 1 (Mon 31) = 21 days.

------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  How many of those 21 days have a winner?
------------------------------------------------------------------
winner-days = Kevin + Kate + Kathy  
      = n + (n-1) + 2n = 4n – 1.

The remaining days have no winner, so

no-winner-days = 21 – (4n – 1) = 22 – 4n ≥ 0  ⇒ n ≤ 5.

Because Kate must win at least once, n ≥ 1.  
Hence n ∈ {1,2,3,4,5}.

------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  How much does each person win or lose in terms of n?
------------------------------------------------------------------
Everyone puts $1 in the pot each day.

• If you are the day’s winner you get the $3 pot: net change +2.  
• If someone else wins you lose your $1 stake: net change –1.  
• If nobody wins you get your $1 back: net change 0.

Kevin  
 wins n days  → +2n  
 loses (Kate+Kathy winner) = (n-1)+2n = 3n–1 days → –(3n–1)  
 NetK = 2n – (3n–1) = –n + 1.

Kate  
 wins n–1 days → +2(n–1)  
 loses (Kevin+Kathy winner) = n + 2n = 3n days → –3n  
 NetKa = 2(n–1) – 3n = –n – 2.

Kathy  
 wins 2n days → +4n  
 loses (Kevin+Kate winner) = n + (n–1) = 2n–1 days → –(2n–1)  
 NetKy = 4n – (2n–1) = 2n + 1.

(The three nets sum to 0, as they must in a fair pool.)

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Express the starting amounts.
------------------------------------------------------------------
By April 1 each has exactly $20.  
Let the amounts in their desks on 3-March be K₀, Ka₀, Ky₀.

K₀  = 20 – NetK  = 20 – (1 – n) = 19 + n.  
Ka₀ = 20 – NetKa = 20 – (–n – 2) = 22 + n.  
Ky₀ = 20 – NetKy = 20 – (2n + 1) = 19 – 2n.

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Choose n to maximise the greatest of {K₀, Ka₀, Ky₀}.
------------------------------------------------------------------
The largest of the three starting amounts is always Ka₀ = 22 + n,
because Kevin starts with 19 + n and Kathy with 19 – 2n.

Ka₀ increases with n, so take the largest admissible n, namely n = 5.

Then

Kevin K₀  = 19 + 5 = 24  
Kate  Ka₀ = 22 + 5 = 27  
Kathy Ky₀ = 19 – 10 = 9.

Kathy never needs more than her $9: arrange for some of her 10 wins to
occur early (e.g. she wins the first 10 days), after which her balance is
well above $1 for the remaining days.  Hence the schedule is feasible and
no one ever runs out of betting money.

Therefore the largest amount anyone could have had on 3-March is Kate’s
$27.

Final answer: $27

Question:
Question: When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
 Hint: For each person, assume they did it. Count how many truthful statements there are?
Hint: For each person, assume they did it. Count how many truthful statements there are?
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
Step 1 –  Translate every statement into a simple logical form  

Let Gx mean “guard x was on duty and left the door open (is guilty)”.

Norris McDim  
   A. ¬GNorris  
   B. GMorris  

Nobby Shifty  
   A. ¬GNobby  
   B. GNorris  

Morris the Daft  
   A. GNobby  
   B. “I hoped Torks would escape.”             ( call this H ; true/false still to be fixed)

Robby O’Mental  
   A. ¬GRobby  
   B. “I was not surprised that Torks did not escape.”   ( call this S )

Step 2 –  Fix the two “state-of-mind” sentences

The story tells us

• “All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape.”

So H is definitely TRUE.

• Because the guards followed Torks’ philosophy they would have expected him not to run away, so saying “I was not surprised …” can certainly be true, but we shall leave S free for the moment and see whether the truth-count forces it.

Step 3 –  Use the information “exactly three of the eight statements are true”.

There are 8 statements in all; exactly 3 must be true.

Try each guard in turn as the guilty one and count the truths (H is already fixed as true).

----------------------------------------------------------------
Assume GNorris (Norris guilty)

Truth values:  
¬GNorris (false), GMorris (false), ¬GNobby (true), GNorris (true),  
GNobby (false), H (true), ¬GRobby (true), S ( ? )

Already 4 statements (¬GNobby, GNorris, H, ¬GRobby) are true; that is more than 3 before S is even decided.  
⇒ Impossible.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Assume GNobby (Nobby guilty)

Truth values:  
¬GNorris (true), GMorris (false), ¬GNobby (false), GNorris (false),  
GNobby (true), H (true), ¬GRobby (true), S ( ? )

Again we already have 4 truths (¬GNorris, GNobby, H, ¬GRobby).  
⇒ Impossible.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Assume GMorris (Morris guilty)

Truth values:  
¬GNorris (true), GMorris (true), ¬GNobby (true), GNorris (false),  
GNobby (false), H (true), ¬GRobby (true), S ( ? )

That gives at least 5 truths, so it is impossible as well.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Assume GRobby (Robby guilty)

Truth values:  
¬GNorris (true), GMorris (false), ¬GNobby (true), GNorris (false),  
GNobby (false), H (true), ¬GRobby (false), S ( ? )

At this point we have exactly three statements true:  
¬GNorris, ¬GNobby, H.

Therefore S must be FALSE (otherwise we would have 4 truths).  
There is no contradiction in S being false – Robby could have been surprised.

This case satisfies the required total of exactly three true statements, and it is the only case that does so.

Step 4 –  Conclusion

The only assignment that fits the “exactly three true statements” condition is that Robby O’Mental was the guard on duty who left the door open.

Final answer: Robby O’Mental

Question:
Question: John, Pete, Tom, George, and Steve are brothers. One day, one of them broke a window. When their father asked them who did it, they gave the following answers:
John: "It was Pete or Tom."
Pete: "It was neither George nor me."
Tom: "Both of you are lying."
Steve: "No, only one of them is lying."
George: "No, Steve, you are wrong."
Then their mother added: "Three of my sons are telling the truth, but I do not believe what the two others said."
Who broke the window?
 Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Human Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Response:
Let  

C = the brother who actually broke the window  
J = the statement made by John  
P = the statement made by Pete  
T = the statement made by Tom  
S = the statement made by Steve  
G = the statement made by George  

Write every statement in logical form.

1. John:  “It was Pete or Tom.”  
    J is true ⇔ C = Pete OR C = Tom.

2. Pete:  “It was neither George nor me.”  
    P is true ⇔ C ≠ George AND C ≠ Pete.

3. Tom:  “Both of you are lying.”  (addressing John and Pete)  
    T is true ⇔ J is false AND P is false.

4. Steve: “No, only one of them is lying.” (still talking about John and Pete)  
    S is true ⇔ exactly one of J, P is false  (J xor P).

5. George: “No, Steve, you are wrong.”  
    G is true ⇔ S is false.

Mother’s remark: Exactly three of the five statements J, P, T, S, G are true.

Because there are only five possible culprits, try each one and see how many of the statements come out true.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
C = John  

 J: false  P: true  T: false  S: true  G: false  
 True statements = 2  ≠ 3  ✗

C = Pete  

 J: true  P: false  T: false  S: true  G: false  
 True statements = 2  ≠ 3  ✗

C = Tom  

 J: true  P: true  T: false  S: false  G: true  
 True statements = 3  ✔︎

C = George  

 J: false  P: false  T: true  S: false  G: true  
 True statements = 2  ≠ 3  ✗

C = Steve  

 J: false  P: true  T: false  S: true  G: false  
 True statements = 2  ≠ 3  ✗
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Only when C = Tom do exactly three statements come out true, satisfying the mother’s condition.  Therefore Tom is the one who broke the window.

Final answer: Tom

Question:
Question: A telephone number has the form ABC-DEF-GHIJ, where each letter represents a different digit. The digits in each part of the number are in decreasing order; that is, ABC, DEF, and GHIJ. Furthermore, D, E, and F are consecutive even digits; G, H, I, and J are consecutive odd digits; and A+B+C=9. What is A?
 Hint: The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Hint: The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Human Solution:
The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Response:
Step 1  –  List the possible middle blocks  
According to the hint the consecutive even digits DEF (written in decreasing order) can only be  
864, 642 or 420.  

The consecutive odd digits GHIJ (written in decreasing order) can only be  
9753 or 7531.

Step 2  –  Try every combination and keep track of the digits already used  
(All ten digits must be different.)

1. DEF = 864, GHIJ = 9753  
   Digits used so far: {8,6,4,9,7,5,3}.  
   Remaining digits: {0,1,2}.  
   For ABC we need A+B+C = 9, but 0+1+2 = 3.  Impossible.

2. DEF = 864, GHIJ = 7531  
   Digits used: {8,6,4,7,5,3,1}.  
   Remaining digits: {0,2,9}.  
   No three distinct numbers from {0,2,9} add to 9.  Impossible.

3. DEF = 642, GHIJ = 9753  
   Digits used: {6,4,2,9,7,5,3}.  
   Remaining digits: {0,1,8}.  
   8 + 1 + 0 = 9, and the three digits are distinct.  
   Arrange them in decreasing order to satisfy ABC:  A=8, B=1, C=0.  
   All ten digits {8,1,0,6,4,2,9,7,5,3} are different, so this works.

4. DEF = 642, GHIJ = 7531  
   Digits used: {6,4,2,7,5,3,1}.  
   Remaining digits: {0,8,9}.  
   No way to get a sum of 9 from three distinct numbers here.  Impossible.

5. DEF = 420 with either 9753 or 7531  
   In each case the digit 0 is already used in DEF, yet C must be different from all other digits.  
   Because 0 would already have been used, any choice for ABC would repeat the digit 0.  
   Hence both choices with DEF = 420 are impossible.

Step 3  –  Conclude  
The only viable full telephone number comes from case 3, and in that case A = 8.

Final answer: 8

Question:
Question: I have 3 dads and 4 sisters. My immediate family (living in my house) consists of 7. Two of my sisters only have 2 dads. How is this possible?
 Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Human Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Response:
Start with the people who actually live in the house.  
• You (the story-teller)  
• Your four sisters  
• Your oldest sister’s little boy – your nephew (the hint)  
• Your mother  

That is 1 + 4 + 1 + 1 = 7 persons, exactly the “immediate family of 7” that share the house.

How can you have three fathers while two of your sisters have only two?  
It all comes from a sequence of your mother’s marriages.

1. Dad #1 – Mum’s first husband  
   – He is the biological father of the three eldest children:  
     • Sister 1, Sister 2 and you (you are the middle child).  

2. Dad #2 – Mum’s second husband  
   – He legally adopted the three older children, so for you and the two older
     girls he is a father as well.  
   – He and Mum also had one child together: Sister 3.  
   – After some years they divorced.

3. Dad #3 – Mum’s present husband  
   – He is now step-father to all the children.  
   – He and Mum had the youngest child together: Sister 4.

Counting fathers for each child
• Sister 1 and Sister 2: biological father (Dad #1) + adoptive/step-father
  (Dad #2) + present step-father (Dad #3)  → 3 dads.  
• You (the middle child): the very same three men  → 3 dads.  
• Sister 3: her own biological father is Dad #2 and she now has step-dad #3  
  → only 2 dads.  
• Sister 4: her biological father is Dad #3 and she has no link to Dad #1,
  so she, too, has just 2 dads.

Thus  
• You indeed “have 3 dads”.  
• You do have “4 sisters”.  
• Exactly “two of your sisters only have 2 dads”.  
• Together with Mum and your oldest sister’s baby the household contains 7
  people.

Everything in the puzzle is therefore possible and consistent.

Final answer:  The children all live with their mother and their oldest sister’s baby, making 7 in the house.  Mum has been married three times, so you and your two older sisters have three fathers (biological dad #1, ex-stepdad/adoptive dad #2, and present step-dad #3), while the two younger sisters, who were born after dad #1 left, each have only two fathers (their own biological dad and the current step-dad).

Question:
Question: There are three brothers: Al, Ben, and Carl. Two of the three brothers are boxers. Here are some facts:
1. The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.
2. The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.
3. The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.
Which brother is not a boxer?
 Hint: Try to come up with a potential ordering of their heights and ages.
Hint: Try to come up with a potential ordering of their heights and ages.
Human Solution:
Carl is not a boxer.
From fact 1, we know that Carl is not the older boxer.
From fact 3, we know that Ben is not the younger boxer.
We now have three possible scenarios:
1. Al is the younger boxer and Ben is the older boxer.
2. Ben is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
3. Al is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
If scenario 1 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al.
If scenario 2 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al; fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al, making Ben shorter than Carl.
If scenario 3 is true, fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al.
We can now expand our three scenarios:
1. Al is the younger, taller boxer, and Ben is the older, shorter boxer.
2. Ben is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
3. Al is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
Scenario 2 cannot be possible because it contradicts fact 2 by making the younger of Ben and Carl the taller boxer.
Fact 2 also tells us that Al is not the shorter boxer, so scenario 3 cannot be possible, either.
Therefore, scenario 1 is true, which means that Carl is not a boxer.
Response:
Let  

•  HA , HB , HC  be the three heights (taller = greater value)  
•  AA , AB , AC  be the three ages   (older = greater value)  

There are exactly two boxers; call them  

O  – the older boxer (older in age)  
Y  – the younger boxer  

1.  “The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.”  
 ⇒  O is the shorter (in height) of Al and Ben. (1)

2.  “The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.”  
 ⇒  The younger (in age) of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer in height.  
 Call the shorter-in-height boxer S; then S is the younger of B and C. (2)

3.  “The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.”  
 ⇒  Y is the taller (in height) of Al and Carl. (3)

Note that S is one of {O , Y}.  
We now try each possible choice for the non-boxer.

-------------------------------------------------
A)  Suppose Carl is NOT a boxer  (boxers are Al and Ben)
-------------------------------------------------
•  From (2): the younger of B and C must be a boxer.  
  C is not a boxer, so that younger one must be Ben.  
  Hence AB  <  AC . (2a)

•  From (1): the shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer;  
  the shorter of A and B is therefore Ben, and Ben is O.  
  Thus HB  <  HA  and AB  >  AA . (1a)

•  From (3): the taller of Al and Carl is Y.  
  Carl is not a boxer, so the taller of A and C must be Al, and Al is Y.  
  Hence HA  >  HC  and AA  <  AB . (3a)

Putting the age facts together: AA  <  AB  <  AC – perfectly consistent.  
All height relations (HB < HA  and  HA > HC) can be satisfied simultaneously.  
Therefore every statement is satisfied when Carl is not a boxer.

-------------------------------------------------
B)  Suppose Ben is NOT a boxer  (boxers are Al and Carl)
-------------------------------------------------
•  From (1): the shorter of Al and Ben must be a boxer, so it must be Al.  
  Hence HA  <  HB  and Al is O. (1b)

•  From (2): the younger of B and C must be a boxer, so it must be Carl.  
  Hence AC  <  AB  and Carl is S. (2b)

But the shorter boxer is Carl, while (3) says the taller of A and C is the
younger boxer Y.  The taller of A and C is Carl (needed to be a boxer), so
HC  >  HA .  Yet (1b) already gave HA  <  HB ; combining those with
HC  >  HA  makes Carl both taller and shorter than Al, an impossibility.
Contradiction ⇒ Ben cannot be the non-boxer.

-------------------------------------------------
C)  Suppose Al is NOT a boxer  (boxers are Ben and Carl)
-------------------------------------------------
•  From (1): the shorter of A and B must be a boxer, so it must be Ben.  
  HB  <  HA , and Ben is O. (1c)

•  From (2): the younger of B and C is the shorter boxer, so it is Carl.  
  Hence AC  <  AB  and HC  <  HB . (2c)

•  From (3): the taller of A and C must be a boxer, so it must be Carl.  
  Hence HC  >  HA . (3c)

(2c) gives HC  <  HB  <  HA , while (3c) gives HC  >  HA – contradiction.
Therefore Al cannot be the non-boxer.

Since the only consistent assignment is obtained when Carl is the sole
non-boxer, we conclude:

Final answer: Carl is not a boxer.

Question:
Question: Andy dislikes the catcher. Ed's sister is engaged to the second baseman. The center fielder is taller than the right fielder. Harry and the third baseman live in the same building. Paul and Allen each won $20 from the pitcher at pinochle. Ed and the outfielders play poker during their free time. The pitcher's wife is the third baseman's sister. The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy, are shorter than Sam. Paul, Andy, and the shortstop lost $50 each at the racetrack. Paul, Harry, Bill, and the catcher took a trouncing from the second baseman at pool. Sam is involved in a divorce suit. The catcher and the third baseman each have two children. Ed, Paul, Jerry, the right fielder, and the center fielder are bachelors. The others are married. The shortstop, the third baseman, and Bill each cleaned up $100 betting on the fight. One of the outfielders is either Mike or Andy. Jerry is taller than Bill. Mike is shorter than Bill. Each of them is heavier than the third baseman.
Using these facts, determine the names of the men playing the various positions on the baseball team.
 Hint: "The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy" implies these three people are part of the union of pitcher, catcher, infielders. The puzzle is filled with these kinds of hints
Hint: "The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy" implies these three people are part of the union of pitcher, catcher, infielders. The puzzle is filled with these kinds of hints
Human Solution: Harry is the pitcher, Allen the catcher, Paul the first baseman, Jerry the second baseman, Andy the third baseman, Ed the shortstop, Sam the left fielder, Mike the right fielder, and Bill the center fielder.

Question:
Question: On Sunday, December 22, four Madadian cruise ships - W, X, Y, Z - started their series of winter cruises to various ports around Madadia.
Ship W left at 4:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 8-days cruises to Madport.
Ship X left at 4:30 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of alternating 11-days and 13-days cruises to Adeville.
Ship Y left at 5:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 5-days cruises to Kebabtown.
Ship Z left on Monday for a series of 7-days cruises.
Each ship is scheduled to return back early in the morning after the last day of the cruise and leave again late in the afternoon of the same day.
On how many days occasions between December 22 and February 28 will three ships be moored at the port?
 Hint: Find out the days on when each ship will be in port
Hint: Find out the days on when each ship will be in port
Human Solution:
On no occasions (other than start date December 22) between December 22 and February 28, three ships will be moored at the port.
Find out the days on when each ship will be in port:
Ship W will be in port on days 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57 and 65.
Ship X will be in port on days 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60 and 73.
Ship Y will be in port on days 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61 and 66.
Ship Z will be in port on days 1, 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58 and 65.
From above data, it is clear that - on no occasion (other than December 22) will three ships be moored at the port.
Also, on 8 occasions, there will be 2 ships moored at the port.
Response:
Step 1 – understand what “a day in port” means  
• A ship that is scheduled for an N-day cruise leaves late in the afternoon of the
departure day, is away for N calendar days, comes back early in the morning of the
(N + 1)-st day and leaves again late that same afternoon.  
• Consequently a ship is physically moored at the terminal for the whole of every
turn-around day; that turn-around day occurs exactly N days after the preceding
turn-around day (counting the departure day as day 0).

Step 2 – list every turn-around day for each ship between 22 Dec and 28 Feb (inclusive)

Ship W – 8-day cruises, first departure 22 Dec  
Turn-around days:  
22 Dec, 30 Dec, 7 Jan, 15 Jan, 23 Jan, 31 Jan, 8 Feb, 16 Feb, 24 Feb

Ship X – alternating 11-day / 13-day cruises, first departure 22 Dec  
(Two possibilities: 11-day first or 13-day first; both are listed)  

• If the first cruise is 11 days:  
22 Dec, 2 Jan, 15 Jan, 26 Jan, 8 Feb, 19 Feb  

• If the first cruise is 13 days:  
22 Dec, 4 Jan, 15 Jan, 28 Jan, 8 Feb, 21 Feb  

Ship Y – 5-day cruises, first departure 22 Dec  
22 Dec, 27 Dec, 1 Jan, 6 Jan, 11 Jan, 16 Jan, 21 Jan, 26 Jan,  
31 Jan, 5 Feb, 10 Feb, 15 Feb, 20 Feb, 25 Feb

Ship Z – 7-day cruises, first departure Monday 23 Dec  
23 Dec, 30 Dec, 6 Jan, 13 Jan, 20 Jan, 27 Jan, 3 Feb, 10 Feb, 17 Feb, 24 Feb

Step 3 – count the number of ships in port on every calendar day

Go through the calendar from 22 Dec to 28 Feb.  The only day on which the
schedules of the four ships place three of them simultaneously in port is

• Sunday 22 December — ships W, X and Y are all alongside until they sail at
  4 p.m., 4 : 30 p.m. and 5 p.m. respectively.

On every other listed date at most two ships are in port at the same time (the
overlaps are W + Z on 30 Dec, W + X on 15 Jan and 8 Feb, X + Y on 26 Jan, W + Y
on 31 Jan, Y + Z on 6 Jan and 10 Feb, W + Z on 24 Feb, etc.).

Step 4 – verify that the result is unaffected by the choice of X’s first-cruise
length  
Whether X starts with 11 or with 13 days makes no difference: apart from
22 Dec all of its turn-around days coincide with at most one other ship.

Result  
There is exactly one calendar day between 22 December and 28 February on which
three cruise ships are moored at the port.

Final answer: 1

Question:
Question: Henry and Gretchen are going to play a game.  Henry explains, "You and I will take turns saying numbers.  The first person will say a number between 1 and 10.  Then the other person will say a number that is at least 1 higher than that number, and at most 10 higher.  We will keep going back and forth in this way until one of us says the number 50.  That person wins.  I'll start."
"Not so fast!" says Gretchen.  "I want to win, so I will start."
What number should Gretchen say to start?
 Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Human Solution:
She wants to say, "6."
The series of numbers she will say is 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.
Since she wants to say 50, she needs Henry to say a number between 40 and 49.  Therefore, she wants to say 39.
Knowing she wants to say 39, she needs Henry to say a number between 29 and 38.  So she wants to say 28.  Following this same logic recursively, she will want to say 17, and she will want to say 6 to start the game, and be assured victory.

Question:
Question: One of four people - two men (Jack and Mike) and two women (Carol and Lily) - was murdered.
The following facts refer to the people mentioned:
(a) Jack's sister argued exactly once with Carol's legal husband after the murder.
(b) Mike's sister argued twice with the victim's legal spouse after the murder. Who was the victim?
 Hint: They may or may not share sisters?
Hint: They may or may not share sisters?
Human Solution:
Mike is the victim.
If Mike's sister and Jack's sister are the same person, then (a) reads "Lily argued exactly once with (Mike or Jack)" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with (the same Mike or Jack)".  These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore Mike's sister must be different from Jack's sister.
If this is the case then there are two possibilities:
1)  Jack and Carol are brother and sister.  Mike and Lily are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Lily and Mike is married to Carol.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Carol argued once with Mike" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with herself", leaving Jack dead.  Since Lily did not likely argue with herself, this is not the solution.
2)  Jack and Lily are brother and sister.  Mike and Carol are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Carol and Lily is married to Mike.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Lily argued once with Jack" and (b) reads "Carol argued twice with Lily", leaving Mike dead.  Since there are no contradictions, this is the solution.
Response:
Let  

 J = Jack (man)  
 M = Mike (man)  
 C = Carol (woman)  
 L = Lily (woman)

Every “sister”, “husband” and “spouse” must be one of these four because the statement says “the following facts refer to the people mentioned”.  
Marriage is monogamous and nobody is allowed to marry a sibling.

Step 1 – Carol’s husband is alive.  
In fact (a) someone argues with “Carol’s legal husband after the murder”, so that husband must still be alive.  
Therefore Carol’s husband cannot be the murder victim.

Step 2 – The two sisters are two different women.  
If Jack’s sister and Mike’s sister were the same woman, then the same person would have argued once and also twice with (possibly) the same spouse, which is impossible.  
Hence

 Jack’s sister ≠ Mike’s sister.                          …(1)

Since there are only two women, one of them is Jack’s sister and the other is Mike’s sister.

Step 3 – Who is Carol’s husband?  
• Suppose Carol’s husband were Mike.  
 Then Mike is alive, so the victim would have to be Jack or Lily.  
 Because of (1) one woman must be Jack’s sister and the other Mike’s sister.  
 If Carol were Mike’s sister she would be married to her own brother – forbidden.  
 If Lily were Mike’s sister she would still have to be different from Jack’s sister, but the only remaining woman (Carol) would then have to be Jack’s sister, making her married to Jack – also forbidden.  
 So “Carol’s husband = Mike” is impossible.

Therefore Carol’s husband must be Jack.                           …(2)

Step 4 – Identify the sisters.  
By (2) Carol is Jack’s wife, so she cannot be Jack’s sister.  
Hence

 Jack’s sister = Lily,                                                …(3)  
 Mike’s sister = Carol.                                             …(4)

(The two sisters are indeed different, satisfying (1).)

Step 5 – Which person can be the victim?  
The sisters Lily and Carol have to be alive after the murder in order to do the arguing, so neither woman can be the victim.  
Carol’s husband Jack is alive by (2).
Thus the only remaining candidate is Mike.

Step 6 – Final check.  
• After the murder the living people are Jack, Carol and Lily.  
• Relation layout: J–C are spouses, M–L were spouses, L is Jack’s sister, C is Mike’s sister.

 (a) Jack’s sister (Lily) argued exactly once with Carol’s husband (Jack). ✓  
 (b) Mike’s sister (Carol) argued twice with the victim’s spouse (Lily). ✓  

Both facts are satisfied and no rule is violated.  
Therefore the only consistent solution is that Mike was the murdered person.

Final answer: Mike

Question:
Question: Walter, Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke crossed a river in a tiny rowboat. They all started on the same side of the river. They made three trips from the starting side to the destination side, and two trips from the destination side to the starting side. Here are some facts:
1. On each trip from the starting side of the river to the destination side, two people were in the boat, but only one person rowed the boat, and that person rowed the boat for the entire trip.
2. On each return trip, only one person was in the boat.
3. Walter is the weakest of the group. He could only row the boat if no one else is in it.
4. Xavier is the second weakest of the group. He can only row the boat if he is by himself or if Yoshi, the lightest of the group, is a passenger.
5. Each man rowed the boat at least once.
Who rowed twice?
 Hint: Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip,.
Hint: Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip,.
Human Solution:
Yoshi rowed twice.
Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip, which means he rowed on at least one return trip.
The man who rowed twice could not have rowed on two trips from the starting side to the destination side, because he would have had to make a third trip by himself back to the starting side. So the man who rowed twice must have made a return trip at least once.
Now we know that if Walter made two trips, they must both have been return trips, and Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke each rowed for one of the other three trips. If Walter made only one trip, the other person who made a return trip must have been the person who rowed twice (Xavier, Yoshi, or Zeke) and that person would also have made one of the other three trips. So the three trips from the starting side to the destination side must have been rowed by Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke.
Fact 1 tells us that Xavier's trip to the destination side must have had a passenger, and fact 4 tells us that that passenger must have been Yoshi. Yoshi would have had to row back to row his trip to the destination side, or else Yoshi rowed to the destination side, then back to the start, then got rowed across by Xavier.

Question:
Question: There is a famous diamond displayed in a room that measures 15 meters by 15 meters by 15 meters. The room is made entirely of concrete blocks and the floor is covered with a thick carpet. The only thing in the room is the diamond that is housed under a glass cube. The glass cube stands on a one-meter pedestal in the centre of the room. Alarm wires spaced eight centimetres apart and running parallel to each other lie under the carpet. The alarm will trigger if more than four kilograms of pressure is applied to any individual wire. Will Carlo who weighs 74 kilograms was able to steal the famous diamond using the following equipment: a five meter 2 x 4 board, four leather straps (each two meters long and five cm wide), a hammer, and a saw. How could he do it without triggering the alarm?
 Hint: How can he spread out his weight?
Hint: How can he spread out his weight?
Human Solution: Will Carlo stole the diamond in the following manner: First, he cut five meter 2 x 4 boards in half. Then using the available straps, he fastened the two boards to his feet like skies. With the boards strapped to his feet, his weight was displacing enough so that he did not exceed the wire's weight tolerance and triggers the alarm. Carlo then slowly and carefully walked to the centre of the room, smashed the glass cube with the hammer, took the diamond and returned the same way he came in.
Response:
The alarm is tripped only when more than 4 kg rests on any single wire.  
Therefore Carlo has to make sure that, at every moment, his weight is divided among at least  

  74 kg ÷ 4 kg ≈ 19 wires.

Because the wires are 8 cm apart, a 1-metre length that is placed at right angles to the wires already touches about  

  100 cm ÷ 8 cm ≈ 12 or 13 wires,  

so a plank a few metres long will rest on many more than the required 19 wires.

Carlo can turn his single 5-metre 2 × 4 into a pair of long “skis” that will always sit on dozens of wires:

1. Saw the 5-metre 2 × 4 into two equal 2.5-metre pieces.  
   (Each piece is about 250 cm long and 9 cm wide.)

2. Using the four leather straps, fasten one plank to each foot—two straps per foot—so that the planks lie flat under the soles like very long skis.

3. Enter the carpeted room and keep the skis perpendicular to the direction of the wires (i.e. cross the wires, not run along them).  
   • Each 2.5-m ski crosses  
  250 cm ÷ 8 cm ≈ 31 wires.  
   • Even if Carlo’s whole weight were momentarily on one ski, any single wire would carry at most  
  74 kg ÷ 31 ≈ 2.4 kg < 4 kg,  
   so the alarm cannot fire.

4. Shuffle or slide across the floor to the pedestal, smash the glass with the hammer, pocket the diamond, and slide back out the same way.

The weight is never concentrated on fewer than 31 wires, so no wire ever feels the forbidden 4 kg. Hence Carlo can steal the diamond without triggering the alarm.

Final answer: He saws the 5-metre board into two 2.5-metre planks, straps one plank to each foot as long “skis,” keeps them perpendicular to the alarm wires, and shuffles across the floor; each ski rests on about 31 wires, so each wire bears less than 4 kg, and the alarm is never activated.

Question:
Question: One day, in baking class, 15 students were baking cakes when the fire alarm went off. Everyone exited the building, but when they got back, they found someone had dumped all the sugar into two of the batter-filled bowls. Everyone was puzzled over what to do until Alice had an idea: why not mix the batters together and then separate the contents back in the bowls. Here is what happened in chronological order:
Alice mixed with Flare
June pours some into Emma's
Luke mixed with Callie
June mixed with Gabbi
Flare mixed with Gabbi
Watt mixed with Tina
Flare mixed with Tina
Luke mixed with Flare
Gabbi mixed with Callie
Daniel, Emma, & Alice mixed with each other
Oscar mixed with Quinn
Misty mixed with Callie
Alice, Misty, & Oscar mixed with each other
Tina mixed with Emma
Kaleb mixed with Quinn
June mixed with Daniel
Luke mixed with June
Ryan, Luke, & Watt mixed with each other
Callie, Alice, & Flare mixed with each other
Kaleb pours some into Daniel's
Watt mixed with Ryan
Watt pours some into Kaleb's
Daniel mixed with Luke
Misty mixed with Gabbi
Kaleb mixed with Tina
Emma & Quinn had no sugar; which 2 bowls started with sugar?
Everyone was able to figure it out.
 Hint: Everyone was able to figure it out.
Hint: Everyone was able to figure it out.
Human Solution:
Luke & Callie
To start, it can't be Emma or Quinn or anyone who mixed/gave to them. This leaves Flare, Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Watt, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Flare because he exchanged with Alice before Alice exchanged with Emma. It can't be Watt because he mixed with Tina before Tina exchanged with Emma. This leaves Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Gabbi because she mixed with Flare before Flare mixed with Tina who mixed with Emma later. This leaves Luke, Callie, Misty, and Ryan.
If only one of Luke & Callie started with sugar it wouldn't be solvable because no interactions happened before them and the outcome would be the same, therefore the solution is either Misty and Ryan or Luke and Callie.
However, it can't be Ryan and Misty because they can't give June sugar!

Question:
Question: Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. will marry one of three women: Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. Here are some facts:
1. Of Audrey and Brenda:
a. Either they both have blue eyes or neither has blue eyes.
b. One has red hair and the other does not.
2. Of Audrey and Charlotte:
a. Either they both have red hair or neither has red hair.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
3. Of Brenda and Charlotte:
a. One has blue eyes and the other does not.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
4. Of the three characteristics; blue eyes, red hair and 5'11":
a. If any of the three women has exactly two of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the least number of characteristics.
b. If any of the three women has exactly one of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the greatest number of characteristics.
Who will Mr. Froopaloop marry?
 Hint: Start with facts 1a and 3a
Hint: Start with facts 1a and 3a
Human Solution:
Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte.
Facts 1a and 3a tell us that Charlotte is either the only one with blue eyes or the only one without blue eyes. Facts 1b and 2a tell us that Brenda is either the only one with red hair or the only one without red hair. Facts 2b and 3b tell us that Charlotte is either the only one who is 5'11" or the only one who isn't 5'11". Fact 4 tells us that no one woman can have one characteristic while another has two characteristics. This gives us two scenarios:
1. Audrey has blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is 5'11". Brenda has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11". Charlotte does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11".
2. Audrey does not have blue eyes, has red hair, and is not 5'11". Brenda does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11". Charlotte has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11".
Fact 4a tells us that in scenario 1, Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte. Fact 4b tells us that in scenario 2, Mr. Froopaloop will marry...Charlotte.
Response:
Let  

• B = “has blue eyes”,  
• R = “has red hair”,  
• H = “is 5′ 11″”.  

Write the three women’s characteristics as 0 (= “No”) or 1 (= “Yes”):

            Audrey   Brenda   Charlotte
            ---------------------------
      Blue       a        a        1–a          (1a and 3a)
      Red        r       1–r        r           (1b and 2a)
      Tall       h        h        1–h          (2b and 3b)

(Explanation of the rows  
• 1a: Audrey and Brenda have the same blue-eye value a;  
  3a: Brenda and Charlotte are opposite, so Charlotte is 1–a.  
• 1b: Audrey and Brenda differ in red hair, so Brenda is 1–r;  
  2a: Audrey and Charlotte agree, so Charlotte is r.  
• 2b: Audrey and Charlotte differ in height, so Charlotte is 1–h;  
  3b: Brenda and Charlotte differ, so Brenda is h.)

Now count, for each woman, how many of the three characteristics she has:
